summary: This document is an email chain from November 2020 between prosecutors in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case and the office of Dr. Cooper, a potential expert witness. The emails discuss scheduling a call to discuss Dr. Cooper's potential testimony regarding child victims of sexual abuse for the trial scheduled for July 2021.

persons.name: Jan Johnson
persons.context: Coordinates scheduling and communication for Dr. Cooper's office, Developmental & Forensic Pediatrics, P.A.

persons.name: Dr. Cooper
persons.context: A doctor with Developmental & Forensic Pediatrics, P.A., whose expertise in child victims of sexual abuse is sought by prosecutors for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case 'United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell', for which prosecutors are seeking an expert witness.

connections.description: Jan Johnson acts as the legal and conference coordinator for Dr. Cooper's practice, scheduling calls on her behalf.
Prosecutors are seeking to engage Dr. Cooper as an expert witness to explain terms and concepts related to child victims of sexual abuse for the Maxwell trial.

events.title: Scheduled Expert Witness Call
events.description: A phone conference is scheduled between Dr. Cooper and the prosecutors to discuss her potential testimony.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The trial for Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin on this date in the Southern District of New York.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case were seeking an expert witness, Dr. Cooper, to testify about child victims of sexual abuse in November 2020.
The prosecutors clarified they were not seeking an opinion on specific case facts, but rather an explanation of general terms and concepts related to the abuse of child victims.
The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled for July 12, 2021, in the Southern District of New York.
The email correspondents include multiple redacted names of Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs) involved in the case.
